The text of "My Own Life" was drawn from the 1898 Green and Grose edition. Page numbers identifying folios refer to page numbers found in Green and Grose.

The text of A Treatise of Human Nature was drawn from the 1911 Everyman's Library Edition. The text was carefully checked against the 1886 Green and Grose edition. Page numbers which identify each folio of the Treatise refer to page numbers of the correlative passage in the Second Edition of Nidditch.

The text of "An Abstract of A Treatise of Human Nature" is reproduced directly from a facsimile edition of the work. Bibliographic information appears on the volume title page. Page numbers refer to the page numbers of the original edition.
This edition of "A Letter from a Gentleman" is reproduced directly from the 1745 Edinburgh edition. Page numbers on reference lines are also from the 1745 edition.

The text of An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding was drawn from the 1898 Green and Grose, but proofread against the 1912 Open Court edition. Discrepancies were arbitrated by the 1758 Hume. The Advertisement was drawn from the Open Court edition. Two page numbers identify each folio: the first, labeled p., refers to page numbers in the Third Edition of the Nidditch Enquiry. The second, labeled gp., refers to page numbers in Green and Grose.

The text of An Enquiry Concerning the Principles of Morals was drawn from the 1898 Green and Grose, but proofread against 1854 Works, with word discrepancies checked against the 1758 Hume. Two page numbers identify each folio: the first, labeled p., refers to the page number of the correlative passage in the Third Edition of the Nidditch Enquiries; the second, labeled gp. refers to the page number in Green and Grose.

The text of Essays Moral, Political, and Literary is a corrected version of the Miller edition (1987) with three exceptions: 1) The bibliographic information included in the footnotes is that of Green and Grose, although the text of the footnotes is that of Miller; Green and Grose altered (primarily added to) bibliographic information in Hume's footnotes; 2) the variant readings are those of Green and Grose, although we have introduced a few changes for reasons of consistency and presentation; and 3) The text of the essays "Of Suicide," and "Of the Immortality of the Soul," is drawn from Green and Grose. Miller and Green and Grose worked from different proof copies of these two essays.

Miller found 100 word and phrase discrepancies, and 175 punctuation discrepancies between Green and Grose and the 1777 Hume. Miller also used the 1772 Hume to check typographical errors in the 1777 Hume. Hence our reliance upon Miller. We are indebted to Prof. Miller and the Liberty Fund for their kindly consenting to our use of their text. Prof. Miller's extensive editorial additions do not appear in this edition.
Two page numbers appear on the reference line for each folio: mp. refers to the page number in Miller, and gp. refers to the page number in Green and Grose.

The reference line for the Essays gives the ESY abbreviation indicating the work, the section of the Essays (Pt. 1, Pt. 2, Wdrawn, or Unpub.), the number of the essay (E. 1, E. 2, etc.) and the paragraph and page number of the folio.
The text of "A Dissertation on the Passions," is drawn from the 1898 Green and Grose Edition. The page numbers in the reference lines of the folios refer to page numbers in Green and Grose.

The text of this edition of The Natural History of Religion, is a corrected version of the 1898 Green and Grose. The page numbers which appear in the reference line of the folios refer to page numbers in Green and Grose.
The text of Dialogues Concerning Natural Religion is a corrected version of the 1854 Works. The page numbers which identify each folio, refer to the Kemp Smith Dialogues.

Hume's History of England is a new variorum edition edited by Prof. Frits van Holthoon. The base text is the edition of 1778, from which the Liberty Classics edition was created. Page numbers are also from the edition of 1778 (duplicated in the Liberty Classics edition). For a complete discussion of the text, see the introduction by the editor at the beginning of the first volume of Hume's History of England.
This is the 1932 two-volume edition of The Letters of David Hume (Oxford, Clarendon Press) edited by J. Y. T. Greig. Page numbers on reference line are from the 193 edition.
This is the 1954 edition of New Letters of David Hume (Oxford, Clarendon Press), edited by Raymond Klibansky and Ernest Mossner. Page numbers on reference lines are from the 1954 edition.
